Process Laboratory Order: Laboratory creates the test results and sends the results to the data repository for availability to the ordering clinician and other providers of care, if appropriate.
Verify integrity of test result (file) contents and that the results came from the identified source.
Authorize release of laboratory test results: Test results released to clinician based on verification as ordering clinician or provider of care status and other appropriate restrictions for use.

Process Request for Laboratory Test Results: The data repository receives a request for test result content and verifies the authenticity of the clinician, the integrity of the request, and any restrictions for use.
The test results should contain appropriate patient information and other information per agreed to standards and policies.
Providers of care should be known.
Where new results cannot be unequivocally matched with a patient, an exception list should be produced to allow human resolution

View results using another clinical data system (non-EHR system): Not all clinicians will initially have an EHR to view lab test results. The clinician may view lab test results using a clinical data system (non-EHR).

Send request for lab test result content to data repository(ies): The clinician selects data repository(ies) from which to retrieve lab test results and sends a request(s). The request is sent via a web application, or other clinical data system.
Lab results are viewed through a web application or other clinical data system.
Print lab results

Save lab results in local system for viewing at a later time: This action assumes that no EHR system is available. The clinician may wish to save lab results to the local system to review at a later time. This is distinct from importing the data into the EHR.

Verify correct patient identity and correctness of lab results and error correct if necessary: Upon review of the result, a clinician may see suspect data (e.g. that should be confidential, or may be erroneous). Error correction communication is a manual process.
Acknowledge receipt of lab results: Upon receipt of the lab result the clinical data system sends an acknowledgement to the NHIE.
Log interaction with data repository
Send acknowledgment to laboratory that integrity, authenticity and completeness of results are found.
Store test lab results
Store lab results in data repository system and note any restrictions for use (e.g., providers of care list, patient consent restrictions, or sensitivity restrictions).
Transmit lab test results to ordering clinician and other providers of care if appropriate
Log receipt and storage of lab test results
Authenticate to locator service
Create test results

Send result location and related information to locator service. This should contain appropriate patient information and other information per agreed to standards and policies. Restrictions for use should also be provided by data repository (from laboratory) if not provided through supporting community or regional services.
Log interaction with locator system
methods to identify and authenticate users.
methods to identify and determine providers of care.
methods to enforce data access authorization policies.
methods to ensure the veracity of data,
methods to correctly match patients across systems.
Clinicians have registered with the HIE and consumer access consents have been established
Clinicians securely access lab test results either through an EHR system (local or remote) or a clinical data system.
Security and privacy policies, procedures and practices are commonly implemented to support acceptable levels of patient privacy and security.
Send results to data repository

Appropriate standards protocols; patient identification methodology; consent; privacy and security procedures; coding, vocabulary and normalization standards have been agreed to by all relevant participants.
Legal and governance policies regarding data access authorizations, data ownership, and data use are in effect.
Secure electronic transport and consent as defined by the HITSP security and privacy constructs is assumed between sender(s) and receiver(s)
The data repository receives a request for test result content and verifies the authenticity of the clinician, the integrity of the request, and any restrictions for use.
The data repository either sends the test results for integration into the clinician’s EHR, or sends the content to another clinical data system for viewing.
The secrecy of the content is maintained during transmission.
Receive and validate the query request
Parse, validate, and acknowledge received data query requests.
Authenticate and verify as ordering clinician or provider of care: May include provider identification and validation of credentials, privileges and/or other authorization.
The laboratory transmits the results to the data repository with appropriate metadata necessary for indexing and browse/query response.

Authentication and verification may be provided through community or regional services. This may include a trust relationship whereby the clinician is authenticated and authorized once by the community or regional service.
The authentication and verification is then carried through the query/retrieval processes.
Test results released to clinician based on verification as ordering clinician or provider of care status and other appropriate restrictions for use.
Transmit lab results of an identified patient to an ordering clinician or provider of care
The means of transport will vary depending on whether an EHR system is available to receive the results, or if a web application is used.

Receive lab test result as ordering clinician or provider of care: New test results, upon completion, may be sent directly to the clinician’s EHR system (local or remote) without an intermediate request action.

Send request for historical lab test result content to data repository(ies): The clinician selects data repository(ies) from which to retrieve lab test results and sends a request(s). The request may be sent from the EHR system or via web application.
Submit authentication information to the data repository
Confirm data integrity of received results: Upon receiving the test result set (messages), the EHR system confirms that the message was received in a complete and unchanged format.
The data repository may be within the laboratory, may be a separate entity, or may be part of a community or regional service provider

Parse and validate results content: The EHR system opens and parses each electronic result. Individual records are checked for appropriate information, completeness, proper codes, and patient identifying information.

Merge data into EHR: The EHR aggregates patient data from each data repository. Each received record is processed and correlated to a patient in the EHR system. Where new results cannot be unequivocally matched with a patient, an exception list should be produced to allow human resolution
New results are flagged within EHR: The EHR system should provide a clear indicator as to the status the review process of all results by clinicians

Acknowledge receipt of lab results: A message is sent to the lab data repository indicating which results were successfully processed and indicates any results that were undeliverable and unprocessed.
Log receipt of lab test results: Include patient consent information in log.
Produce exception list of errors: Where inbound lab results records cannot be unequivocally matched with the EHR, an exception list is produced to allow human resolution

Query for laboratory (historical) test results: The clinician queries the locator service for the availability and location of lab test results for a specified patient and receives the location of the results.
Queries to the locator service could be accomplished either through the EHR user interface directly or through another clinical data system.
Submit authentication: Establish clinician’s identity and verify whether clinician is a provider of care
Receive test results from laboratory.
One of many authentication methods could be used (biometrics, card, token or user ID and password, cryptographic techniques).
Clinician and locator system agree on patient identity through patient trait matching
The clinician and locator system must verify that they are interacting about the same patient.

Patient identity may be agreed upon by a number of means including demographic information, agreed-to mapping of patient IDs, or shared patient ID.The means is dependent on whether the locator service is provided by a third-party, or part of available community or regional services.
A set of traits (such as name, DOB, gender, etc.) may be used by a locator service to perform a probabilistic match.
Business rules could be established across a community or region to determine minimum acceptable combinations of traits (for example, name-only searches not allowed without a DOB).
Provides the functionality for a priori agreed to identifiers by the clinician and locator service and lab data repository.

Clinician and locator system agree on patient identity based on shared MPI: If the entity to which the clinician is affiliated (hospital, HMO, private physician practice, etc.) has already registered the patient internally and uploaded the entry into a shared MPI, the provider can capture and submit the entity's internal identifier for that patient (e.g., the patient's medical record number for that hospital) to a locator service.
artifact.art_content: In this case, the provider would not need to manually enter demographic traits (name, date of birth [DOB], etc.) since that data are already present in the MPI.

artifact.art_title: Clinician and locator system agree on patient identity based on patient identifier matching
The locator system matches the patient identifiers supplied by the clinician with patient identifiers known within the locator service.
The laboratory test results as well as any pertinent information necessary for indexing and browse/query should be provided.

Transmit request for specific lab test results based on order number or other unique test result identification: The clinician may request specific test results based on a unique identification number, eliminating the need for browsing through all available test results. This can be performed through a web application or through a standards-based query request from the clinician’s EHR.
Browse, select and confirm the relevant test results for the correct patient and transmit request

Based on the patient information provided by the clinician (either the entity identifier or demographic traits), a list of candidate patient matches will be retrieved from the locator service. This list should contain demographic data that will help the clinician determine which of the potential matches actually corresponds to the patient. ...
artifact.art_content: From the list of candidates previously retrieved, the clinician will select and confirm the entry or entries that correspond to the patient and those applicable to reason for query (e.g. date range, test groups, etc.). The clinician may also determine that none of the candidates in the list are correct matches.

artifact.art_title: Receive the data repository location where the test results are stored: The locator service provides pointer (i.e., links) to the location(s) where the test result(s) are stored. The clinician uses these locations to retrieve the test results.
Log interaction with locator service
Clinician should have proper identification/authorization to access patient-specific information everywhere such information exists;
Clinician should be able to uniquely identify patient for which information has been requested;
Clinician request will return ALL information available for the specific patient; and
Proper action should be taken when results updates are sent for error correction, completeness, etc.

Clinician should have proper identification/authorization to access and review patient-specific information

Provide lab result availability information based on clinician query/browse
Authorize data release: Test result information released to clinician based on verification as ordering clinician or provider of care status and other appropriate restrictions for use.
Send lab result location (links) pointers to authorized clinician: The location pointers will be used by the clinician to retrieve the lab test results for either viewing or integration into the EHR.
Log interaction with clinician

The system shall allow authorized personnel to access records via secure connectivity from anywhere, at any time.
The system provides patients with a unique login and password.
The system shall provide patients the ability to securely view physician approved medical data and lab results.
The system shall have a secure message capability whereby patients can send messages to the practice and vice versa.
The system shall allow patients to view their demographic data and insurance information, and make changes to demographic information.
The system shall allow patients to schedule their own appointments.
The system shall comply with HL7 to interface and import/export data from other HL7 compliant systems.
The system shall allow providers to create pre-defined templates.
The system shall support prescription printing and faxing.
The system shall route reports with attached notes for others to review.
The system shall allow physicians to review diagnosis from previous encounters.
The system shall allow data to be displayed as flow sheets and growth charts for analysis.
The system shall allow select outside providers to be copied on results.

The system shall prevent the creating of duplicate patient records.

The system shall track no-shows and cancellations.
The system shall allow the user to define color coding for appointment types and reasons.

The system shall support hand recognition so a provider can notate directly to a patient's electronic record.
The system shall allow specified users to create prescriptions for physicians to approve.

The system shall allow physicians to generate prescriptions via their favorites list.
The system shall allow the patient to fill out questionnaires/paperwork in advance through the portal.

The system must record the patient.
The system must provide the ability to update data if the patient is in the system.
The system must record the admission, including the initial diagnosis.
The system must have a patient waiting list.
The system must support the request for an interpreter for the arrival time.
The system must allow a case to be transferred to someone else.
The system must allow acess to the state of the patient.
The system must provide an overview of planned services and results.

The system must be able to show all reports on the screen as well as on print.
The system must give customer rights to use the tools and extract the data stored in the system.
The system must use NHC data that is reasonably recent.
The system can allow IT support to roll NHC data back to the previous version.

The system can periodically transfer data from the new system.

The system must require a password only if the system has been logged out automatically.
The system must check that only authorized users have access to systems and data.
The systems must require each user to have only one user name and one password.

The system must provide security management the ability to create a user.

The system must enable each role to have one or more rights.
The system must allow the creation of new role types with new combinations of rights.
The system must provide an overview of who has which rights and whether some rights have not been assigned to anyone.
The system must protect against the loss or replication of data transferred between two systems.
The system must protect against concurrency problems.
The system must protect against a disk crash.
The system must protect against a fire.
The system must protect unintended user actions from causing the system to close down, neither on the client nor on the server.
The system must check all data for format, consistency and validity.
The system must warn the user if format, consistency or validity are in doubt.
The system must allow the user to correct mistakes easily.
The system must provide the user with the ability to interrupt long functions.
The system must protect against unauthorized persons obtaining manager rights through the internet.
The system must protect against wire-tapping of passwords.
The system must protect against unauthorized persons from getting access to personal data.
The system must require error messages to be understandable and helpful.

The system must be designed so users can learn the system on their own.

The system must not slow down the user's typing speed when moving from one field to the next.

The system shall improve accessibility of online clinical information and results.

The system shall provide a means to view patient demographics, allergies and adverse reactions, postings (cautions, warnings, allergies, and advance directives), clinical reminders, current medications, problems, appointments, etc.
The system shall improve efficiency of entering orders.
The system shall provide a way for user to quickly click on the specifications that he or she wants for each order placed.
The system shall provide an option to so a user can quickly set up orders for frequently placed orders.
The system shall allow several orders to be placed with the ability for a user to sign for them all at once.

The system shall allow complete order sets to be predefined and personalized.
The system shall allow order checking.
The system shall provide background checks on duplicate orders, drug-drug interactions, and many other criteria that a user can choose.
The system shall integrate orders with progress notes, results, procedures, diagnosis, and Problem List.
The system shall mimic traditional order entry processes where necessary to accommodate established clinical practices.
The system's design shall follow hospital work flow patterns and allow local site and individual customization to make it fit specific needs.
The system shall provide real-time order checking, as well as extended expert system/decision support capabilities that enhance the order entry process.
The system shall integrate all components of the patient record to provide comprehensive and intelligent clinical information access and reporting.

The system shall allow multiple use and integration of information, including cutting and pasting among components, boilerplate capabilities, templates, etc., thus decreasing the amount of duplicate entry of data.
The system shall be easy to use by improving the user interface to reflect industry standards and principles of usability and user-centered design.

The system shall allow setting of business rules, document types, user classes, etc. to control access to documents, reports, verification, signing, and so on
The system shall support the Ambulatory Care Date Capture project for capturing encounter data for workload credit, as well as capturing clinically relevant data for reminders and reports
The system shall have pre-defined progress note templates.
The system shall allow creation of personalized templates to fit the specific needs of individual practices.
The system shall include clinical reminders to provide relevant information to providers, at the point of care, for improving patient care.
The system shall include a graphing feature to allow users to view lab test results and vital signs in a graph.

The system shall include a report construction feature so each site can individually run related to patient data including: Health Summary, Vitals Cumulative, Nutritional Assessment, Daily Order Summary and Order Summary for a Date Range reports.
The system shall support role-based access for security controls.
The system shall support audit capability.
The system shall support requirements for codified data, including diagnosis data using ICD-9 codes.

The system shall have the capability to capture and store risk, social and medical factors; including, but not limited to the following: Tobacco use and history including number of years and packs per day (PPD), Alcohol use history, Drug use history, Occupational environment, Marital status, Occupation, Religious preference, Ethnicity, Healthcare surrogate with alert, Guardian/legal representative with alert.
The system shall document discharge summary hospitalization data, as well as procedure and diagnosis-related information.
The system shall capture history of received immunizations.
The system shall include capabilities for ordering laboratory tests and reviewing results.
The system shall allow medication orders to be placed and filled from local stocks of medications while providing full auditing of all medication orders within the medication profile.

The system shall provide the following pediatric functionality including: Pediatric progress note templates based on the Indian Health Services (IHS) progress note templates and American Academy of Pediatric Bright Futures templates
The system shall provide OB/GYN progress note templates based on the IHS progress note templates.
The system will provide the ability to register patients of all types.
The system shall have the capability to capture and store risk, social, and medical factors for each new patient.
The system shall allow physician offices to use social security numbers or medical record numbers to identify patients.
The system shall support the requirements for codified data specified by the DOQ-IT quality improvement measures.
The system shall trigger registration reminders when patient meets eligibility requirements for the DOQ-IT program.
The system shall include Standard Laboratory and Medication orderable files.
The system shall include the ability to print prescriptions for signature and fax prescriptions to a local pharmacy with an electronic signature.
The system shall provide a platform for building interfaces to external lab services enabling automated order entry and results reporting.
The system shall provide an open source integration platform to build interfaces to Billing/Practice Management systems.
The system shall require handwritten signatures for outpatient medication orders of schedule 2 and schedule 2n controlled substances due to DEA policy.
The system's pilot program shall use a smart card to digitally sign medication orders.
The system shall require a smart card reader, smart card, and a PIN to digitally sign an order.
The system shall require most orders or documents, such as progress notes, reports, or health summaries, to have an electronic signature.
The system shall not release orders to services or activated until they are signed if they require a signature.
The system shall not require a signature for an order if the order is designated as "signed on chart" or a generic order that does not require a signature.
The system shall implement a user class hierarchy to identify the roles that different users fulfill within the hospital.
The system shall provide tools for creating business rules that apply to documents used by members of such groups.
The system shall provide a method for identifying who is AUTHORIZED to do something (for example, sign and order).
The system shall define, populate, and retrieve information about user classes.
The system shall allow user classes to be defined hospital-wide or more narrowly for a specific service.
The system shall allow user classes to be used across VistA to replace and/or complement security keys.
The system shall allow infinite hierarchies of subclasses to be created in the User Hierarchy Class structure.
The system shall allow document types to inherit authorizations from a higher level when using classes to assign roles.
The system shall impose no limitation on the depth or specificity of the User Class hierarchy which a site may choose to develop.
The system shall allow concurrent membership in more than one User Class.
The system shall automatically considered any member of a given User Class to be a member of all superclasses of that class.
The system shall automatically include membership in a given User Class to all member of subclasses of that class.
The system shall design the Kernel Person Class File to accommodate the HCFA National Provider System Taxonomy of Professionals/Occupations.
The document-handling system (TIU) shall include Consults/Request Tracking, Discharge Summary, and Progress Notes.
The document-handling system (TIU) shall have boilerplate and cut and paste capabilities.
The system shall allow other VistA applications to access the user class file to determine the role of an employee.
The system shall require provider, location, date and time encounter data to be entered for each visit (or telephone call) with a patient.
The system shall require service connection, provider name, location, date, diagnosis, procedure, and visit information to be entered in the enounter form to receive workload credit.
The system shall timeout after a period of inactivity.
The system shall ask the user if the user wants to continue using the system before timing out.
The system shall require the entry of an access code and a verify code to gain access to the system.
The system shall stored the names of users who view remote data in the remote site's database.
The system shall audit sensitive records, enabling a site to follow up on a record accessed by a remote location.
The system shall provide a way to limit the users or sites that have access to remote retrievable data.
The system shall allow users who hold any of the ORES/ORELSE/PROVIDER keys to be viewed as a clinical user and has full access privileges to all problem list options.
The system shall view users who hold the OREMAS key to be a clerical user, and, consequently, the verify, remove, restore, and view removed options will not be available.
The system shall enforce these access levels when problems are entered via the encounter form. Problems entered on the encounter form by clerical personnel shall be left as UNVERIFIED.

The system shall require a unique match in the Medication, Dosage, Route, and Schedule fields for inpatient medications before CPRS will auto-select an item from the list. The system shall require the Medication and Schedule fields to be an item from the list for inpatient medications, but the Dosage and Route can be a free-text entry (the route must be in the MEDICATION ROUTES file #51.2).
The system shall allow users to enter time in several different formats.
The system shall require times to be entered as a 24-hour time, not with a 12-hour clock and an a.m. and p.m.
The system shall require a user to review and sign changed if a user has just entered orders or documents that are unsigned.
The system shall only auto-select(highlights in blue and places that entry in the field) a patient name if the user types enough characters to uniquely identify a name in the list.
The system shall wait until the user explicitly selects an item using the mouse or the keyboard if the user does not enter enough characters to uniquely identify an item.
The system shall display a box listing possible matches if CPRS finds more than one patient with the same last name and same last four digits of the social security numbers.
The system shall allow the user to group the patient list according to provider, team, specialty, clinic, or ward.
The system shall use a set of characters that include uppercase and lowercase Latin alphabetic characters (A-Z, a-z), numbers (0-9), and other special characters.
The system shall sort characters based on their numeric values in the character set that VistA uses.
The system shall display a message indicating the patient’s ability to pay for medical services must be evaluated.
The system shall display a message that a patient has data from the legacy system used before the site was consolidated that is not being displayed which a user may want to access.
The system shall indicate that the record is sensitive and may only be viewed by authorized users.
The system shall display a message telling the user that the selected patient is deceased.
The system shall display a message of possible matches if more than one match is found when a user partially enters a patient's name and last four digits of a social security number.

The system shall allow the creation of patient lists or team lists that simplify tasks such as reviewing patient charts, ordering, and signing orders and notes and these lists can be based on wards, clinics, teams, or other groups.
The system shall use patient lists allow a person to quickly locate patients without going through all the patients in the list.
The system shall allow clinicians to create patient lists for who can sign or cosign for each other.
The system shall ensure that all team members receive necessary information about a patient by using patient lists to tie notifications to teams.
The system shall allow notifications to be renewed if the user decides the alert should not go away when the user views it.
The system shall allow a user to foward notification to someone else at the site.
The system shall allow users to disable unwanted notifications as desired.
The system shall not allow mandatory notifications to be disabled.
The system shall retain notifications for a predetermined amount of time (up to 30 days), after which they may be sent to another destination, such as your MailMan surrogate or your supervisor.
The system shall only display notifications for a user's patients or notifications that have been forwarded.
The system shall sort notifications based on column heading: Info (information alerts are preceded with an “I”)
The system shall sort notifications based on column heading: Patient name (alphabetical or reverse alphabetical)
The system shall sort notifications based on column heading: Location (patient location, if known, alphabetical or reverse alphabetical)

The system shall sort notifications based on column heading: Urgency (valued HIGH, Moderate, or low as indicated by the CPRS parameter ORB URGENCY. TIU alerts are given a Moderate urgency value. Other alerts without a parameter value are given an urgency of low.)
The system shall sort notifications based on column heading: Alert Date/Time (date/time the alert was triggered, newest to oldest or oldest to newest)
The system shall sort notifications based on column heading: Message (alert message or text, alphabetical or reverse alphabetical)
The system shall sort notifications based on column heading: Forwarded By/When (sorts alerts alphabetically and then by time for the same forwarding person)
The system shall store which column the user sorted by when the user exits or changes patients and sorts by that column again when the Patient Selection/Notifications screen is next displayed.
The system shall update diagnostic and procedure codes used for billing purposes so codes are applicable at the time the service was provided.
The system shall check ICD and CPT code validity as of a specified date when codes are entered, when a new code set is implemented, and whenever CACs or IRM personnel choose to run the option.
The system shall indicate problems with inactive codes have the “#” symbol in the status column.
The system will abort when the user tries to login if tabs are not assigned to the user in their NEW PERSON file or if the RESTRICT PATIENT SELECTION prompt does not contain a Yes or No.

The system shall allow the CAC, or whoever is responsible for granting access to the CPRS GUI at each site, to assign the appropriate access each time a new user is added to the system, or if restricted access is needed for existing users.
The system shall require the user to have acess to the Clinical Coorindator menu in the List Manager Interface to assign CPRS tab access.
The system shall require an OEER List to be defined to contain the selected patients in order to grant restricted access to the CPRS GUI.
